turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Sydney Street Appellant versus New York.
Mr. Goldstick.

turn.speaker: david_t_goldstick
turn.label: Mr. David T. Goldstick
turn.text: Good morning Mr. Chief Justice.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Before you start, I should have said that the orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice and filed with the Court below will not be announced thoroughly.
You may proceed now Mr. Goldstick.

turn.speaker: david_t_goldstick
turn.label: Mr. David T. Goldstick
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court.
This is an appeal from a conviction of the Criminal Court of the City of New York, where an appellant was convicted for malicious mischief.
And that he be filed and cast contempt upon and burned an American flag in violation of Section 1425 (16) (d), of the New York State Penal Law.
The charge was that he did willfully set fire to and burn the American flag and shout, “If they did that to James Meredith, We don't need and American Flag”.

The judgment was unanimously affirmed by the appellant term of the Supreme Court of New York without decision, and in turn, the Judgment unanimously affirmed by the Court of Appeals, Judge Fuld rendering the opinion.
The statute in question is set forth in page 5 of appellant's brief.

I might, at the Halter say that we agreed completely with Justice Fuld when he states that the central issue in this case is whether or not the deliberate act of burning an American flag in public as a protest maybe punished as a crime.

Parenthetically, we believed there was another issue that was raised then and that is raised here today, that assuming that New York State may punish such an act as a crime, may it do it under the statute in question.

The facts are really undisputed, on June 6, 1966 at about 5:30 in the afternoon, Sidney Street was sitting in his apartment listening to the radio when he heard news broadcasts that James Meredith, while marching through Mississippi was shot.

He went to his door to get an American Flag when down from his apartment to a street corner, put a piece of paper in the street folding the flag in one hand, properly fold it, put a match to it, and set it on fire.

A police officer testified at the trial that he saw the smoke, came over to find out what had occurred, saw on the street corner a flag partially burned and folded lying on the ground, heard a man shouting, couldn't quite make out what he was saying.
At the other street corner across the street, heard a man shout, “We don't need no damn flag!” Upon identify who the man was who it turned out to be the defendant.
Asked him if it was his flag, the appellant said “Yes, it was my flag”, and said the words “If they did that to James Meredith, We don't need the American Flag”.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Goldstick, Judge Fuld and his recital of the facts and his opinions for the Court of Appeals.
It does have a little minor error in his factual recital does he not?
When he says that your client told the small crowd which collected that quote “if they let that happen to Meredith, We don't need an American Flag”.

turn.speaker: david_t_goldstick
turn.label: Mr. David T. Goldstick
turn.text: Now, we don't know if factual error then and I'll tell why Mr. Justice, because they also testified that he came over after the burning and that he questioned the person street there at the corner.
Now, I don't know whether when he questioned him loud enough for the crowd to have heard the question.
I think we may assume that he did.
Certainly, we may assume that the crowd did hear “We don't need no damn flag”, that's without question.
The other words, with the records just doesn't clear Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I went to the record pretty carefully yesterday and I didn't see that there was anything to support the statement that you're client as he was burning the flag --

turn.speaker: david_t_goldstick
turn.label: Mr. David T. Goldstick
turn.text: Oh, that's quite so.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: It put it off, so he came told the small crowd that he collected --

turn.speaker: david_t_goldstick
turn.label: Mr. David T. Goldstick
turn.text: Oh that's quite so.
The statement was made after the act of burning was done, quite so, quite so.

Let me ask the Court if they will turn with me to page 5 of my brief so that we may examine the statute together and that I might point out what appellant's contentions are concerning the infirmities of the statute.
I turned to the subdivision d, which it says, “Shall publicly mutilate the face, the file or defy, trample or cast contempt upon either by words or act.”
At the outset, it becomes obvious that the insertion in the statute by words, as well as by acts, shows us that the statute on its phase restricts freedom of speech.
Secondly, I would like to point out that the word “Cast Contempt Upon”, the words cast contempt upon, the word defile, the word defy, have speech meanings as well as act meanings.

As a matter of fact, I find difficulty in seeing where the statute does not, on it's face, have an absolute restriction on the form of verbal speech that somebody may use towards the American flag and this is born out I might say in the District Attorney's brief where he so interprets the statute even in the Court of Appeals' decision.
I asked the Court to turn with me for a moment to Judge Fuld's decision on page 8a of the record.

About 12 lines from the bottom of the page, we see the observation by Chief Judge Fuld, subdivision 16 of section 1425 is designed to prevent the outbreak of such violence by discouraging contemptuous and insulting treatment of the flag and I infer from the words “treatment” that treatment certainly had contemptuous treatment of the flag maybe by word as well as by act.

We find that the opinions of the Mr. Harry Brodbar General the State of New York, as cited in the District Mr. Harry Brodbar's brief, seem to indicate that the statute is prohibiting words as well as acts.
In fact, it seems to go farther even then the Court of Appeals' decision.
The Mr. Harry Brodbar General seems to feel that all disrespect of any kind shown to the flag is illegal under the statute.
Now, the point that I'm trying to bring to this Court's attention is that this is not a fanciful observation.
The convictions that we had in New York over the past two years have been really real besides streets conviction.

We had a conviction in the Riddick's case that is waiting appeal to the New York Court of Appeals where an owner of an art store, a displayed in his arts store in the window, some 40 odd constructions of an artist's protest against the American flag and as Judge Bissell, observed in his descent, the artist is conveying by his pictures what you or I might be able to convey by words but this is the way he can convey it best.

You'll notice in our reply brief, in our reply brief, we have a picture of a poster and I've noticed that Mr. Justice Stewart is taking a look at and I think maybe all of us could look at it together.

At two weeks ago, a police officer was--had issued a summons for violation of the statute for showing an American flag in a bookstore window and replacing on the field where the stars are the doves of peace, and the signs of peace.
Now the question has to be asked, alright what does have to do with this case.

No question that streaked at something that isn't all speech, its act as well as speech and alright, suppose the statute goes too far but we should still be able to convict Street because unquestionably, New York has the power to outlaw this kind of conduct.

It is our position Your Honors that even if this Court took that position which we would not agree at with but assumed for a moment that we agree that the State of New York could outlaw this type of conduct.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: You know really, do you really argue that State of New York could not constitutionally outlaw the defacing of the flag by physical acts?

turn.speaker: david_t_goldstick
turn.label: Mr. David T. Goldstick
turn.text: I do not Mr. Justice Fortas.
I do not take that position.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: You don't take that position?

turn.speaker: david_t_goldstick
turn.label: Mr. David T. Goldstick
turn.text: I do not.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: So, it's a speech element here that or the speech or so called “symbolic speech” about issue you here.

turn.speaker: david_t_goldstick
turn.label: Mr. David T. Goldstick
turn.text: It bothers me very much and it also bothers me that a statute on its face that is so restrictive goes far beyond the limited powers that Mr. Justice Fortas is referring to, and that even if we assume that it could do what Mr. Justice Fortas says, I quite agree with you and all likely we're going to probably could.
It can't go as far as the statute and Mr. Street is in a position to attack the statute.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Now, Mr. Goldstick, I didn't quite understand, what position do you not take?

turn.speaker: david_t_goldstick
turn.label: Mr. David T. Goldstick
turn.text: I do have the position that the State of New York had not regulate conduct towards the flag.
I'm saying that the State of New York may, under certain circumstances with a properly drawn statute narrowly construed for the purpose intended, prevent certain acts of flag desecration.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I didn't understand your brief to take that position.

turn.speaker: david_t_goldstick
turn.label: Mr. David T. Goldstick
turn.text: You know, last night I really struggled with this problem myself because I've been struggling with it for two years, and I must confess to Your Honor that I have been back and forth on the power of the state to regulate conduct towards the flag, and I have to take the position that in this case it makes no difference, whether or not we were to decide that the State of New York does have such power.
I'm willing to concede for the purpose of this argument that it does have that power.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Just for this branch of your argument or your whole case?

turn.speaker: david_t_goldstick
turn.label: Mr. David T. Goldstick
turn.text: I'm willing to concede for the entire case that there is a limited amount of power that the State of New York has to regulate conduct, conduct towards the flag.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I take it though you would say that power ends as just the moment that the conduct is communicative.

turn.speaker: david_t_goldstick
turn.label: Mr. David T. Goldstick
turn.text: Absolutely.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Even though and it ends as soon as there is a claim that is communicative?

turn.speaker: david_t_goldstick
turn.label: Mr. David T. Goldstick
turn.text: Well, I would say first, we may not even have to reach that point because the statute on its face, obviously, restricts communicative acts.

So that -- even if we have for example a statute like the Federal Government recently enacted which omits completely any reference to speech except, I might point out for the word “defile” which has an interpretation having speech connotation.
Assume even that word was out, and we had a federal statute in question, which then have to reach the question there as to whether was constitutionally applied, but we can avoid that problem.
Though, I'm prepare to speak on it because I think even if we have the federal statute of New York, that particular facts in this case would not allow a conviction.
But assuming for a moment, that was the statute we had, I'm sorry.
Assuming that we did not have the statute but we have the statute that we have, we don't reach the question because that's far beyond the federal statute.

I might point out that the honorable Ramsey Clark and I realized it is not binding in this Court at any matter whatsoever, but he still made a very have observation to Congress when they were adapting their statute that the words as used in the New York statute deter and in the proposed statute before the Congress will very much like the New York statute.
And freedom of speech --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Let me see if I follow you because your concession doesn't dispose in a matter for this Court, but I want to get your position clear.
Suppose you had here a statute that said that, that should be statute of New York that said it should be unlawful for any person in public deliberately to set fire to and burn an American flag.
That's all the statute said, I understand that's what Mr. Street did, and he was indicted for that, no speech element whatever.
You do not take the position that that would be a violation of the United States Constitution.

turn.speaker: david_t_goldstick
turn.label: Mr. David T. Goldstick
turn.text: I do not.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I'd like an addition to that.
He uses some language, do you claim with that purged him?

turn.speaker: david_t_goldstick
turn.label: Mr. David T. Goldstick
turn.text: I'm sorry Mr. Chief Justice --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But if an addition to burning the flag, he uses some language such as he does here?
Do you think that purges him of burning the flag?

turn.speaker: david_t_goldstick
turn.label: Mr. David T. Goldstick
turn.text: That is the nub, isn't it?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I beg your pardon.

turn.speaker: david_t_goldstick
turn.label: Mr. David T. Goldstick
turn.text: That is the nub of the problem isn't it, because that is exactly what we are saying.

We are saying also that even under the circumstances, these circumstances Mr. Justice Fortas pointed out, that the act could then be coupled with other acts that in and up itself now brings it out of the simple due process problems of a criminal statute and close it with First Amendment problems.
And I might point out --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Don't you think there'd be any First Amendment problem and the case put to you by Mr. Justice Fortas?

turn.speaker: david_t_goldstick
turn.label: Mr. David T. Goldstick
turn.text: Not necessarily.

Not necessarily because on its face, there's no restriction of speech, but there may be as for example as apply, the person may be doing the burning and shouting that United States is not belong in that--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: What if he has not saying anything?

turn.speaker: david_t_goldstick
turn.label: Mr. David T. Goldstick
turn.text: No words?
Well, there is no --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Don't you think there's First Amendment problem?

turn.speaker: david_t_goldstick
turn.label: Mr. David T. Goldstick
turn.text: No, I don't see where the communication is.
There has to be a communication in order for them to --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Don't you think that's a communication ended up itself?

turn.speaker: david_t_goldstick
turn.label: Mr. David T. Goldstick
turn.text: Not necessarily, if I filled myself with a couple of statute, I'm sorry.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But it is.
It doesn't say word --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: david_t_goldstick
turn.label: Mr. David T. Goldstick
turn.text: Could it be.
The answer to that would be if --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You mean that we have instead of word here that same word with -- it is like you --

turn.speaker: david_t_goldstick
turn.label: Mr. David T. Goldstick
turn.text: If Street had not said a word -- not necessarily.
I'm trying to get to the -- to the not necessary part.
If the burning of the act, at the burning of the flag took on a secondary meaning, for example if this was a protest where people realized that the burning was for a purpose of protest.
There was a communication, before Kleenex was on the market for example for number of years, the word Kleenex has no secondary meaning but it got a meaning because people got using it.

The same thing with draft card burning, today when a fellow burns a draft card in public, we very well know what he was doing, it was usually that he was communicating a protest against the Vietnam War.
Flag burning hasn't got that secondary meaning but I submit it may very well get to that point.

But that isn't our problem at this time, I'm willing to concede right now that simply that -- simple act of burning the flag in New York, but not under the statute, would be --could be illegal because the statute goes far beyond that problem.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Yes, I might question which you've answered, I assumed that I postulated that the statute did not contain, did not contain any reference to verbal statements but the New York statute does since you pointed out?

turn.speaker: david_t_goldstick
turn.label: Mr. David T. Goldstick
turn.text: I agree with Mr. Chief --Mr. Justice --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: I'm not indicating in the attitude of the --

turn.speaker: david_t_goldstick
turn.label: Mr. David T. Goldstick
turn.text: I understand.
I might point out--

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: -- or in the language of the New York statute in this respect does and does not make a difference but you answer to my question was very carefully restrictive.

turn.speaker: david_t_goldstick
turn.label: Mr. David T. Goldstick
turn.text: Thank you.
I might --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: May I ask you a connection with the precise argument you are now making.

What do you say about this statement Giboney v. Empire Storage Company, but It has never been deem that abridgement of freedom of speech or prayers, to make a course of conduct illegal merely because its a conduct was in part initiated evidence, or carried out by means of language, either written, spoken or printed.

turn.speaker: david_t_goldstick
turn.label: Mr. David T. Goldstick
turn.text: Mr. Justice Black, I hope by the time I finish today, and after this Court has seriously considered the merits of this case that that statement would not be the law of this land.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: In other words, we'd have to overrule this.

turn.speaker: david_t_goldstick
turn.label: Mr. David T. Goldstick
turn.text: I'm not saying that because you don't even have to reach that question because we have a statute on its face that it breaches freedom of speech that you don't even have to reach that problem.
What I am saying however --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Why don't you have to reach it, if you say that the conduct itself did not violate the Constitution, but it does violate it because of the language use at the time?

turn.speaker: david_t_goldstick
turn.label: Mr. David T. Goldstick
turn.text: The reason Mr. Justice Black, I say we don't have to reach it is because, Street was convicted under a statute that is unconstitutional on it's face as being a obvious restriction on verbal speech, it says you can't use words and that he has a right I believe, to attack that statute and thereby attack his conviction even though New York may well have the right to outlaw exactly what he did.
And I think Thornhill against Alabama is exactly that type of a situation.

But to get back to your question Your Honor, I would like to feel that the issue here on an act as well as words is whether a communication was made and whether the communication was understood, because isn't that truly the problem of a freedom of speech case.

The communication of an idea to the public and the receipt of that communication by the public, and this is the nub of the issue that Mr. Justice Black has referred to, and this is the nub of the other issue of this case which I freely admit does not have to be reached.
But if reached; should be decided on drawing criteria for us to know when act and speech is speech and when act and speech is not speech, and therefore not entitle the First Amendment protection.
If I might digress just for a moment --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: May I just ask you about it?

turn.speaker: david_t_goldstick
turn.label: Mr. David T. Goldstick
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I noticed that Judge Fuld's opinion doesn't deal with your argument which I gather as an argument of overbreadth that because the statute deals both with conduct and words this appellant has standing to attack constitutionally of the statute on its face.
That's your argument isn't it?

turn.speaker: david_t_goldstick
turn.label: Mr. David T. Goldstick
turn.text: Yes it is.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Now, why is it that Judge Fuld's opinion didn't deal with that?

turn.speaker: david_t_goldstick
turn.label: Mr. David T. Goldstick
turn.text: He dealt with it only on a footnote.
I'll show you--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Which footnote?
I raise this because I gather the states going to content does at least in its brief that was not considered because you did not raise it.

turn.speaker: david_t_goldstick
turn.label: Mr. David T. Goldstick
turn.text: We did.
And it was considered Your Honor, at page 4a of the decision, footnote 1.
We raise the entire argument of overbreadth in vagueness in the Court of Appeals --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But how bout the trial court?

turn.speaker: david_t_goldstick
turn.label: Mr. David T. Goldstick
turn.text: And well, at the trial court, I might point out that if you have an examination of the record.
As I was making my motions, I was politely asked really to sit down.
We never really got the finishing making our emotions, and not only was at the issue to discuss that the trial court, but it was also discussed at the Court of Appeals and dealt within that motion.
But I might point out Mr. Justice White, that the overbreadth argument is a First Amendment argument, it's not a Fourteenth Amendment argument.
We raise First Amendment question.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So?

turn.speaker: david_t_goldstick
turn.label: Mr. David T. Goldstick
turn.text: I would -- it would be my understandings provided any issue on First Amendment infirmities raised and in any manner what so whether, whether be overbreadth or void on its face or improper application of the statute would still be a First Amendment objection and properly raised --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, what would you say if we have -- we taught we had to read Judge Fuld's opinion as not twiddling of a question because as a matter of State Law your failure to raise a trial included any right to have it consider in the appellate courts.
If we have to read it that way, then where do you stand?

turn.speaker: david_t_goldstick
turn.label: Mr. David T. Goldstick
turn.text: But I -- of course if you read it as if I did not raise it but it was raised that you see raised in my motion at the trial court I raised First Amendment objections I said the statute is void for First Amendment problems and Judge Fuld pass on First Amendment problems and there whole question of overbreadth is First Amendment not a vagueness or due process problem.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What if the Court disagree with you on that and since said that you have to raise a little more precisely --

turn.speaker: david_t_goldstick
turn.label: Mr. David T. Goldstick
turn.text: I have no argument with Mr. Justice White if that is your decision certainly under the rules of this Court --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: It is First Amendment raises all issues under the First Amendment?

turn.speaker: david_t_goldstick
turn.label: Mr. David T. Goldstick
turn.text: I would believe so that it does.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Do you have to – is that – do you have to rely on that?

turn.speaker: david_t_goldstick
turn.label: Mr. David T. Goldstick
turn.text: No, not to and this case?
If I have raised First Amendment – as far as the overbreadth I would say, yes.
But as far as the applications --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: As far as overbreadth is you have to rely on that position?

turn.speaker: david_t_goldstick
turn.label: Mr. David T. Goldstick
turn.text: Yes, I would.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Did you think them as this is the rule of New York that – is it the general rule at to that the appellate court doesn't consider things is not – that their not believe in that one?

turn.speaker: david_t_goldstick
turn.label: Mr. David T. Goldstick
turn.text: Not so because the Court of Appeals are considered the vagueness question which was not raised at the Criminal Court level.
The vagueness question though dispose of in a footnote was still considered.
We have pointed out that the statute was vague because he never said what flag they were talking about.
That was disposed of in a footnote and that was the total consideration given to the vagueness argument by Judge Fuld.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, except there's something else that the fact is bothered me Mr. Goldstick and that reason I ask you about your answer to Justice Fortas question.

Judge Fuld in Footnote 1, appearing on 4a of the appendix of this case, it seems to say before the highest Court in New York that this statute simply prohibits public mutilation of the flag and that's why the way he construes the statute.
And of course, we have to take that construction as though the statute were written that way under we've excepted conventional doctrines in this Court.

turn.speaker: david_t_goldstick
turn.label: Mr. David T. Goldstick
turn.text: In due deference to Your Honors observation, I again refer back to page 8a of the opinion as to the construction and the statute and it seems to me that the language by discouraging contemptuous and insulting treatment of the flag in public is a construction given to this statute by Judge Fuld and I might--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: What do you think for that first footnote means the last phrase in it, “That the provision was meant to apply to public mutilation of the American flag.”

turn.speaker: david_t_goldstick
turn.label: Mr. David T. Goldstick
turn.text: I can't answer that question.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, it means obviously its means something you and I would have to agree.

turn.speaker: david_t_goldstick
turn.label: Mr. David T. Goldstick
turn.text: Of course, it mean something but I think there's another – there's another answer to your question Your Honor and that is simply that the construction of the Court of Appeals was not available to the Criminal Court judge when he tried the case.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Now, I suppose you could -- the whole of your function that page the --

turn.label: Mr. David T. Goldstick
turn.text: Page 13 a

turn.label: Justice Byron R. White

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: It would be the clerk and the officer.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You don't know?

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: No.
But I know from custom in New York Court that is the clerk and the officer who do it.
Then the case comes before the Judge.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, when did the prosecutor get involved?

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: When the case which its turn in the calendar, the Assistant District Attorney came into the case and tried the case as we say --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: So, he had taken that language out?

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: Did he do what, Your Honor?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Could he have taken the language out of that charge?

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: He could have but he did not --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But he didn't?

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: He did not Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: So, the State of New York insisted that this charge include both the act and the language that was the decision of the State of New York, am I right?

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: Well, that's the effect of that but Your Honor, Mr. Justice Marshall, in every case when an office or even a book making case, or on a policy case an officer would set forth exculpatory statements.
The mere fact that exculpatory statements are set forth is that mean that is part of a statute.
The officer feels that it's better for this case to set forth language.
It explains the intent, the man's rare --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I suppose the manner in which the Court of Appeals decided that would have somebody to do with the state law concerning the complaint, would it not?

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: Yes, Mr. Chief Justice.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And the Chief Judge Fuld did say as it was pointed out by one of the other Justice, “We are called upon to decide whether the deliberate act, the burning in American flag in public as a protest may be punished to the crime.”
And I suppose that if that -- if arrest of the text conforms to that I suppose that we can consider that's all there is in the case for us, is it not?

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: Yes, Mr. Chief Justice.
And the words deliberate are not only brought out by the conduct but also by the words set forth in the complaint.
And I reiterate that the words were not necessary, that the facts indicate contemptuous treatment of the flag by Mr. Sidney Street, that there was no in advertence or accidental occurrence.
This was planned that the people who's partly around him did not collect Your Honor because he did an In adverted Act.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I like then to hear Mr. Brodbar your submission upon the hypothesis that you are entirely right that we can disregard the reference in the statute to the word words and we can equally disregard the reference in the complaint to the quotation of what the defendant allegedly said.

And that we're dealing here, therefore, simplicity with the question I suppose by Chief Judge Fuld in the very first paragraph of his opinion for the Court of Appeals simply with a state's statute that makes it a criminal offense to publicly burn an American flag.

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: Yes, Mr. Justice Stewart.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And that because the claim is that with which Chief Judge Fuld had to deal for his Court that a state could not constitutionally make that a criminal offense.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But while you're considering that -- did you suggest that or do you agree that the only way that you would know it is a protest in the words that were used.

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: No, from his conduct.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Okay.

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: From his agitated condition, from his anger.
One does not simply burn a flag with contend gently.
There's an atmosphere, it is an emotional about an act like that when a mute -- a deaf mute can show contempt for the flag by burning it.
Can we say that the deaf mute would not be a subject of the conviction?
Because he cannot say what the language what he means.
It's what he does and how he does it.
That spells out the content for the flag that standing in this Courtroom.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, then since I -- perhaps you hadn't finish answering my Brother White's question.

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: I did answer.
I did complete.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I meant to add to my question, the very publicly burn an American Flag in public as a protest, that question that Chief Judge Fuld puts may that constitutionally be punished was a crime but it --

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: Yes it may Mr. Justice Stewart.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, then why?
Why?
That's my question.

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: Because it interferes with substantial state interest.
Just as an O'Brien against United States, there was a substantial State interest, Government interest that a man had a draft card.
There are substantial interests here.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: What is the equivalent of interest here or the or the common law interest here?

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: The interest here that Americans love their flag and anyone seeing a flag defiled will --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That's not comfortable.
I don't believe Americans love their draft cards, isn't it.

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: There was no -- a draft card does not have the significance of a flag.
The flag has great meaning.
If a flag has no meaning at all it means that every man who dies for this flag was not only dope by the flag but it made a mockery out of patriotism.
That every man who lies on only cemetery died for something that was just a cloth, a piece of cloth, which had no meaning at all to them and now we say the flag has no meaning.
It is like a -- it is greater than a draft card.
We are inculcated with the spirit of a flag from early childhood.
A card is nothing in reality.
It does not send me to retaliation with one were to burn his draft card.
I might be annoyed what the infantile conduct.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, I take it you've read the Court's opinion in O'Brien against the United States?

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: Yes, I have Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And I take it down that you seem that the many pages of that opinion were devoted to the showing of the public interest, the national interest in the possession by young man with their draft card.

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: Yes, Mr. Justice Stewart.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: What is the equivalent or --

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: There is a national interest in the American flag.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: First of all, you of course have to argue what the state interest is?

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: The State interest is to protect the national symbol because the state is part of a nation.
If a nation does not exist the state will not exist.
In Halter against Nebraska the first Mr. Justice Harlan said to the state has the same interest, an interest to course respect not to mandate respect as a bond that but to prevent desecration.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That's the case of course was decided long before it had been held at the Fourteenth Amendment incorporates the First Amendment.

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: Yes, Mr. Justice Stewart.
But the case still has great significance today.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Mr. Brodbar, let us suppose that you had a case involved only words, words expressing the at most contempt in hatred for the American flag.
Now, with those words standing alone fall within the condemnation of this statute.

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Now, that's the nub of the trouble here.
I agree with you that electro reading of this statute would catch words standing alone because subsection d of the statute makes up the crime public relate to defile or defy or -- let me take this.
Let me withdraw that.
Public relate to cast contempt upon the American flag by words.

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: Well, Mr. Justice Fortas this is not --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Now, if that's what the statute says, doesn't it?

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: And our question as whether we can -- whether we are at liberty to ignore that in effect for purposes of this particular case.

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: Mr. Justice Fortas, we maintain that the statute is divisible that this Court may ignore the language of the statute which speaks of words because the opponent was and I think before action --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: All right, now, do you attempt to in the defense, suppose it's not divisible.

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: I intend --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: If you attempt to defend the constitutionality of a New York statute that said only that, “it shall be a crime to cast contempt upon the flag by words.”

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: Yes, I do.
I defend it because the words of contempt get the same result as the acts of contempt.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: I see.

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: Words are just the same words as we had, they're fighting words, they're the words that we had in Chaplinsky against New Hampshire, when a man's flag is degraded?
Do we not degrade the man himself?

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Well, then why do you --

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: Do we not say you are a citizen of a country, are these not worth nothing?

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Right.
Why do you say then -- why do you argue then that the statute is divisible?

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: Well, in the event that this Court should it in its wisdom feel that the words are unconstitutional, that we'd be blessed with some statute.
That is the only purpose I say that.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Do we have to read Judge Fuld's opinion as being broad enough to include what you say?

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Do you think it does go that far?

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: Well, it appears that way, because Chief Judge Fuld makes the statement, “Subdivision 16 of Section 1425 is designed to prevent the outbreak of such violence by discouraging --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Where is that?

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: That is on page 8 a of the record.
“It's designed to prevent the outbreak of such violence by discouraging contemptuous and insulting treatment of the flag in public.”

It is our opinion and this was me a dictum -- victim in a case, but it shows the inherent feeling of Chief Judge Fuld speaking for the entire Court that even if this case had just words in it that the decision might be the same.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: This treatment necessarily include words?

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: Yes, treatment is a broad term and includes conduct, it includes words, it's an attitude, it's a behavior.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Can I say something, suppose there was no burning at all and I just say something contemptuous of the flag, is that treatment of the flag?

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: In common parlance?

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: Yes, Mr. Chief Justice Warren.
Treatment of the flag, when one insults another he treats it wrongly, does he not?
The word treatment is a general word.
But I say if the Court was not concerned at the particular time of the decision with any words, but just with the act.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, then why do you say that it includes words, if it wasn't considering anything but acts?

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: I would say this was an observation made by Chief Judge Fuld by way of passing.
He may have meant the act --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: You told me a moment ago that you thought it was broad enough his opinion was broad enough so that we would be obliged to include words as well as action.

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Conduct?

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice Warren, the way Chief Judge Fuld starts the case, we are concerned with the act where he says thereafter is not part of this determination as he'd started out to say, where he said, “We are called upon to decide whether the deliberate act of burning.”

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, that's what I was trying to get at, but I understood you departed from that.

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: No, I would say that the --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: In answering me and said that his opinion was broad enough to include language if there was no burning, and you say that the word treatment to show that.

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: Well, my point is this that the Court was concerned primarily with the conduct.
The Court was not considering the word itself, the language used by Judge Fuld later on is dictum that is the opinion I have.
And it's also in my belief that if the defendant had been charged with words only and no act at all that the decision would have been the same.
But the Court was concerned only with the act, it prefixes its opinion with the statement.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Do you say that's your opinion that the decision would be the same?

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: That is my respectful opinion, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: It's your opinion that that judge and those judges would sustain statute which did nothing in the world would make it unlawful from a man to speak of views about the flag, is that right?

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: Well, speaking views about a flag may convey a message, what message is there in contempt?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What are the -- there are language, the speech you have hear, speech mix with conduct?
Why do you have to defend the idea that New York has power to make it a crime for man to speak and say something bad about the flag?

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: No, I'm not saying that Mr. Justice Black, I am saying that criticizing the flag is one thing.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But why, do you have to go that far in this case?

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: No I don't Mr. Justice Black.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Why do you get into it such factual --

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: I am concerned with this Court's attitude with regards to words, and perhaps that this Court may decide that part of the statute is dead.

I am here, not to defend my flag in quiet whispers, but to try to defend the entire statute and we've open the door to contempt by use of words should this Court find that the act is proper, the act is actionable, that is my purpose.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Your view are judge is that if a man says something, make his speech about his views, he has committed a crime and that the First Amendment doesn't excuse him?

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: No, I did not say that.
He can express his views, but contempt, profanity, obscenity toward a flag is not a message.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, is it not obscenity?

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: Well, how else can one --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Maybe it is, I've never know exactly?

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: How else can one show contempt for the flag by way of words, except by the use of epithets, obscenity or profanity, and if he does it that way, what is the message he is conveying?
Is he trying to change government?
There is no message at all.
He recognizes nothing good in America when he said that, he has consign America to the flames of obscurity, that is not the message.
If he said that our country is not giving me the proper rights.
That is a message that deserves respect under the First Amendment because at least the governmental self improvement, but to desecrate a flag by words, leaves no message.
What is he trying to say, that our government is bad because of this?
Because of that?
He says nothing.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Suppose he did say the Government was bad, that's the object to the First Amendment is to permit who is criticizing Government and its institution.

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: But the statute does not cover criticism in ‘pure language, it covers contempt, defiance.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, that's criticism.

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: Criticism is a --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I have an equal statute it prohibits two things, one is the conduct of burning a flag, that's what I understand with Judge Fuld.
The other is it attempts to condemn a man from making a speech that is critical or as you say contemptuous of the Government.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Or the flag, of the flag.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You mean as a Government's institution.

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: But when he talks about the flag, he's not talking about.
He is talking about its disaster, it's anarchy, it's chaos.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: No, as I understand your statute, it would cover this kind of a statement, “I'm a very loyal American, as a matter of fact I think there's nothing wrong with our nation, I think it's just perfect.”
But frankly, I think our flag is one of the homiest ugliest flags” --

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: There is nothing wrong with that, when a parent says that my friend's daughter is prettier than mine, does she show less love for his daughter?

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Oh no, now wouldn't your statute cover my hypothetical case?

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: No, it would not.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Why not?

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: Because that is not the contempt that is meant, our favorable criticism are not just point of view.
Someone maybe partial to certain colors, that is not the contempt meant.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Oh, it talks about contempt upon the flag, not upon the country.

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: Criticism is not contempt, if my adversary is shorter than I am -- I show no contempt by saying that.
Mere criticism of a flag as to its color scheme or design is not contempt.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Very contemptuous of its color scheme.

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: Well, if you were serious, I would still think it was not contempt.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I think you have to test the statute out by what it might cover don't you, when you have a constitutional question?

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: Well, the point is the defendant was charged and convicted of the act of burning, so this talk about words might not be before this Court, but I hope it stays before the Court.
Pardon me Mr. Justice Black?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You insist on arguing in that length, and so that is your whole case.

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: The whole case --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: In other words, contempt.

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: The case deals with only the appellant's act of burning a flag, but it is our wish, the wish of the State of New York that this Court would determine the entire statute.

And if it should hold that the words are in violation of the First Amendment, that the act be divisible, that the statute be divisible and that they be left for the State of New York to enforce desecration by act.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Does it contain a Separability Clause?

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: It does not but the logical reading of it, the federal statute just pass, does not have words, so it could stand alone, it could stand with just the act --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I'm not talking about the federal statute, I'm meant about yours.

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: There is no language in the statute which --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Do they have in general rule as to what's construing thing as separable if there are two separable crimes in New York?

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: No, but there is a strong presumption of constitutionality and there is also a presumption that every part of the statute fall that the rest may remain, unless it is impossible to keep the remaining part of the statute --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Why would you say that's a presumption --

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: The presumption of constitutionality is the strongest presumption.
However, if the Court should feel that part of the statute is dead then there is also a presumption, the remaining part of the statute can stand, unless that it's impossible to consider itself.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That's the law of New York?

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: That is the law of the nation, the law of --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I'm talking about New York.

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: Yes, we have a construction statutes in New York to give these meaning to a statutes that if part of a statute is bad, the Court will try to uphold a balance, unless it is impossible for it to stand alone.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Very well.

turn.speaker: harry_brodbar
turn.label: Mr. Harry Brodbar
turn.text: Thank you.

turn.speaker: david_t_goldstick
turn.label: Mr. David T. Goldstick
turn.text: Just one point Mr. Chief Justice.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: No, I think you've finished your argument.
You've take a few time.
